citations.narrative:
A Crab-eating macaque was observed chewing on a long strip of material which had been removed from a swing.
Ingestion of the material could potentially cause injury to the animal. Housing facilities for nonhuman primates must be
designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound for the species of nonhuman primates housed in them. They
must be kept in good repair, and they must protect the animals from injury, contain the animals securely, and restrict other
animals from entering.
Corrected at time of inspection.

An outdoor enclosure for two African crested porcupines had a hole in the end wall with sharp points extending from the
bent metal. The back of the enclosure had a metal wire panel on the ground that was exposed to the animals. This is a
potential source of injury or possibly entrapment to the enclosed animals. The sharp points need to be removed or
secured. The wire panel needs to be removed or covered. All housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be
maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury.
To be corrected by June 1, 2025
In the large outdoor enclosure housing sika deer, blackbuck, fallow deer, goats, sheep, and zebra, there are several
railroad ties that have metal rods with sharp points exposed to the animals. This is a potential source of injury to the
enclosed animals. The railroad ties with sharp extending rods need to be removed. All housing facilities shall be
structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury.
To be corrected by May 30, 2025
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
William Snow, SUPERVISORY VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.75(a) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
A Crab-eating macaque was observed chewing on a long strip of material which had been removed from a swing. 
Ingestion of the material could potentially cause injury to the animal. Housing facilities for nonhuman primates must be 
designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound for the species of nonhuman primates housed in them. They

Corrected at time of inspection. 
3.125(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
An outdoor enclosure for two African crested porcupines had a hole in the end wall with sharp points extending from the

potential source of injury or possibly entrapment to the enclosed animals. The sharp points need to be removed or 
secured. The wire panel needs to be removed or covered. All housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be 
maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury.  
To be corrected by June 1, 2025 
 
In the large outdoor enclosure housing sika deer, blackbuck, fallow deer, goats, sheep, and zebra, there are several 
railroad ties that have metal rods with sharp points exposed to the animals. This is a potential source of injury to the 
enclosed animals. The railroad ties with sharp extending rods need to be removed. All housing facilities shall be

To be corrected by May 30, 2025 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.

Additional Inspectors: 
William Snow, SUPERVISORY VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
